results.title: Entertainment
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at recreational activities in China. Cinema going is particularly popular and European and American films are being shown more frequently. The Peking Opera is a much loved and traditional art form, steeped in cultural heritage. Although it is not as popular amongst young Chinese, tourists love the rich pageantry. The Chinese also love outdoor events in parks and on waterways. The composition of Chinese characters in Chinese writing is also examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Health
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras explores the many ways in which the Chinese people look after their health. Hospitals may be run by Government Departments for workers. Apart from conventional medicine, traditional therapies such as Acupuncture and Moxibustion are widely accepted. Herbal remedies are also important to Chinese medicine and many pharmacies carry both manufactured drugs and herbal treatments. This program also looks at the composition of a character when practising calligraphy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Families
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at the importance of family in Chinese culture, especially since the law restricted family size to one child in order to contain the population. Chinese Law since the 1950’s forbade polygamy and arranged marriages, and now young people can choose their own partners. The status of women and girls is discussed and the problems encountered raising single children. The program also looks at oracle bones and how these lead to the creation of written language.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Dragon's tongue
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A series of lessons in the Chinese language intended for high school students who have studied Chinese for two years. Each lesson includes some simple vocabulary, calligraphy, brief dramatisations which utilise the vocabulary and short sections on life in modern China. Introduced by Colin McKerras.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Centred around various festivals, particularly the Spring festival or Chinese New Year, this program looks at the lion dance, the use of firecrackers weddings, birthdays and the Chinese national day. Vocabulary learnt is centred around time, with examples being, “How long?”, “time off”, “often”, “How many?”. Professor Colin Mackerras attends a wedding and explains how a wedding is celebrated, and some of the traditions associated with birthdays. The calligraphy section shows various characters for different festivals. There are dramatised sequences which show a family celebrating the Spring festival, and a birthday, and we also witness a performance of “Waltzing Matilda” in Chinese.

results.title: The Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This program looks at the Peking Opera genre of juggling and acrobatics. Vocabulary in this section is concerned with questions such as “Do you perform often?’ and “Is Peking Opera difficult to learn?” Other sections include a look at jade, the “Yang qin” ( a Chinese musical instrument), three short dramatisations and a calligraphy section on the character for skill and its derivatives. Presented by Colin MacKerras.

results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Colin McKerras introduces this lesson, which centres on work. He introduces vocabulary associated with work, such as “How many days a week do you work?” and “What do you want to do when you leave school?” We see workers in a factory in Beijing and talk to school students about their future plans. The calligraphy section shows the character “to produce” and associated characters for “production”, “products” and “maternity leave” The two dramatised sections “Work or study” which depicts a Chinese family in Australia, and “Work experience” showing a student on work experience assignments, include much of the vocabulary introduced. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Country life
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at life in the country in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with a Chinese duck farmer, a look at Chinese script (the seasons) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin, and English.

results.title: Sightseeing
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at sightseeing in China. Tourist spots like the 13 Tombs are visited. The video is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. It also includes an interview with a Chinese tourist guide, a look at Chinese script (the city wall) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

Episode number 5 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at sightseeing in China. Tourist spots like the 13 Tombs are visited. The video is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. It also includes an interview with a Chinese tourist guide, a look at Chinese script (the city wall) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at school and school life in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with Chinese school students, a look at Chinese script (to study), the erhu (a Chinese stringed instrument), and short dramas in Chinese. The interview questions are repeated in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.
